message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation affects the intron/exon boundaries, where splicing occurs during mRNA processing. This can result in abnormal splicing, leading to a malformed protein. Frameshift, missense, and nonsense mutations affect the coding sequence directly and typically result in a truncated or non-functional protein rather than a malformed protein with an altered length.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation affects the splicing of RNA and can result in abnormal protein production. This is consistent with the observation of a malformed protein in the boy’s red blood cells. Frameshift, missense, and nonsense mutations all can affect protein production, but they do so in different ways than a splice site mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Splice site mutations affect the splicing of mRNA, leading to changes in the downstream protein product. This is the most likely explanation for the malformed protein in the boy's red blood cells. Frameshift mutations, missense mutations, and nonsense mutations can also lead to abnormal protein products, but they do not specifically affect mRNA splicing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation can cause abnormal splicing of RNA, leading to a malformed protein that is longer or shorter than normal. Frameshift mutation, missense mutation, and nonsense mutation can also cause abnormal proteins, but they typically result in a shorter or nonfunctional protein. In this case, the protein is longer than normal, suggesting a splice site mutation.

We refer to basic genetics concepts for help. A mutation in the splice site will affect the proper processing of pre-mRNA and lead to a protein with an abnormal length. Frameshift mutation, missense mutation, and nonsense mutation all result in a different amino acid sequence or a premature stop codon, which are unlikely to account for the specific protein length change mentioned in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation occurs when there is an error during the splicing of pre-mRNA, which results in a defective protein being produced. In this case, the malformed protein is longer than the normal, healthy protein, indicating that there may be an error in splicing that is adding additional amino acids to the protein. Frameshift mutation, missense mutation, and nonsense mutation would result in shorter, truncated, or non-functional proteins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation would cause a portion of the protein to be missing, resulting in a malformed protein. Frameshift mutation, missense mutation, and nonsense mutation all involve changes in the DNA sequence, but they do not specifically result in a portion of the protein being missing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the protein is malformed suggests a mutation in the DNA sequence, and of the options, only splice site mutation can cause mis-splicing of the pre-mRNA, leading to abnormal protein synthesis. Missense mutations change a single nucleotide, resulting in a different amino acid. Nonsense mutations create a stop codon early, terminating protein synthesis prematurely. Frameshift mutations alter the reading frame of the DNA sequence, resulting in different amino acids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation occurs at the junction between intron and exon, and can lead to incorrect splicing and alteration of the final protein product. This can cause beta thalassemia, which is characterized by malformed hemoglobin proteins. Frameshift mutation, missense mutation, and nonsense mutation can all cause genetic diseases, but they do not specifically account for the finding of a malformed protein with altered length.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A splice site mutation affects the normal splicing of intron-exon sequences, leading to the formation of abnormal proteins. This is consistent with the abnormal protein length seen in the patient's red blood cells. Frameshift and nonsense mutations would result in truncated and non-functional proteins, while missense mutations involve a single amino acid substitution.
